text:
Thank you very much
for the brave space

that we continue
to co-create here.

Thank you, Robin, for laying
this generative foundation

and remaining dedicated and
committed to this space.

Thank you, Lakshmi,
for everything

that you do to
curate this space.

Thank you for continuing to open
up the space within this space

for us to feel in keeping with
the theme of this program.

I also, just as you'll
see and hear and testify

for yourselves, you
know, I'm concerned.

I'm concerned about where
we are, where we come,
where we're going.
And I also have hope.
My hope comes from the arts.

I believe the arts are what
is keeping the planet alive.
So thank you for this space.

I visited Monticello, which
was the home and the plantation

that Thomas Jefferson, the
third president of the United

States, author of the
Declaration of Independence,

and architect and founder of Mr.
Jefferson's Academical Village,

also known as the
University of Virginia.

I visited for the
first time this week.

My family has been
laboring in some way

through the course
of seven generations
at the University of Virginia.

This was the first
time that I had

gone to Monticello with an
executive education group.

And so I found out that in
1824, Marquis de Lafayette

visited Thomas
Jefferson at Monticello.

And Lafayette implored
Jefferson to build

the integrity of the Declaration
of Independence and the freedom

ideals into the structural and
moral integrity of Monticello

and all of the
other institutions
that he had built and led.

Jefferson declined,
saying that he recognized

there were problems
with slavery,

but that was problem for
another generation to solve.

So Lafayette came
back and said, "well,

could you at least help to
prepare the enslaved Africans
for freedom?

Let them learn how
to read and write,"

which at Monticello, was
happening informally,

under the cloak, and wasn't
being penalized in the same way
that it was in many places.

But here's where
Jefferson drew a line.

Jefferson said, "Sure, we'll
teach them to read print,
but they must not write.

Because if they do, they'll
write their own freedom
papers."

Truer words have
never been spoken.
So I love my freedom.

Love, love, love freedom
I am enraged that it
is being stripped away.

I am fearful and I am
anxious for the deafening
silence in its wake.

Like Jefferson, I fear those
who choose profit and popularity
over personhood.

The Chief Diversity
Officer of my state
last week declared DEI dead.
And so therefore I am grieving.

And as I think of the theme this
year, tools, love, and rage,

that grief is one of the purest
expressions of a combination
of love and rage.

Grief is the tool that
awakened a planet.

I'm grieving the stain for
intellectual discourse.

I'm airing my grievances,
whether I'm told
I'm too much or not enough.

I'm grieving the dearth
of the tender hearted

urges to alleviate
suffering, the lack

of sacrificial choices, to just
pass the mic or the mantle.

I'm grieving the resurgence
of all deliberate speed.

I'm grieving the lack of
courage to just press send.

Just say the thing that
unlocks the gateway.

I'm grieving the
loss of potential,

what could have been allowed
if they'd possess the freedom

to live the full length
and the full width of life,

a loss of hope and anticipation
for many futures that may never

be, grieving a
loss of conviction

and short-lived attempts to
overpromise and under-deliver

with no shame, grieving
my innocent worldview,

that everyone would just be
kind, play fair, or else.

Grieving a lack of consequences,
grieving feeling safe

as a child inside of my
mind-you-own-business cocoon

of Gary, Indiana when it
was designated as the murder

capitol of the United
States of America.

And now that I live in
the nation's capital,

I'm grieving the lack of safety
and consequences for murderers.

I'm grieving a place
in which love is love.

And yet those of us
who grieve bear witness

to the life that remains,
to the blood that
still flows through our veins.

So I think I have
time for two pieces.
That was just the beginning.
Those weren't the actual pieces.

The first piece is called
"The Crown Act II."

And I wrote this
piece in November

to recognize the loss of life
of three University of Virginia

football players and the
loss of the full length

and breadth of life
of the individual

who took those lives of Lavelle
Davis, Devon Chandler, DeSean
Perry.
Some of you will get this.
Some of you may not.

When Black people lose Black
leaders, it hits differently.

Because we know what it
took for them to get there.

And so that's what
this is about.

It's for all of us,
but there's something

uniquely textured
and complex about how
we experience these moments.

And I just wanted to give a
testament to that and to them.
Our grief is jet black.

It is flowing like deep
rivers of chocolate, buried

in sandy tan shores and mahogany
roots, planted in rich soil,

parted in sharp zigzag
rows, signaling fuel

to be reaped on
the way to freedom.

It's laid and layered
with textures.

And try as you might
to brush them aside,

they refuse to conform
to any uniform.

Contoured by untimely
winds, blowing tides

changing, too soon,
too late, unrelenting.

Leaving waves of disbelief
and anger and resolve

unyielding, drenched in ripples
of guilt and mercy and hope

unbending, tinted
with despondency,

fiery swirls rising up,
smoothing over unruly,

bristled from whispers
of regret and fear

and holding and releasing
too close, too far,

moisturized in tears,
cleansing salts, curl tight,

Bantu knots gathered and tied
in unity, banded and bonded

in pain, braided and
locked in purpose.

Angled toward the sun, never
to be tamed by the heat,

beholden to its natural
state, imperfect, imprecise,

infinitely coiffed,
and genuinely good.

A tangled tapestry of
contradictory patterns

that defy codes, letters,
numbers, assigned to coils,

sewn in or glued onto
jerseys, onto charters,

onto license plates, onto
prison badges, onto zip codes.

Wrapped in dreams, I'm
left to mask or manifest.

Silver linings and gray
edges, pressing on faith,

unresolved, split ends,
dangling, lingering,

unbreakable precious jewels
and memories held tight,

uniquely shaped,
trendsetting, stylish,

and fashioned into
permanent crowns.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
Thank you.

So the second piece is called
"How to Win the Culture War."
A cacophonous choral response.

But no, we really are
all over the place.

On guard, Armor up, hands
up, no handouts, no call

outs, call in, lean in, buy
in, sit-in, walk out, movie on,
left behind standing in line.

Without my mask, my
fast pass got canceled.

Got that leg up climbing
mobile educating myself out
of this ghetto.

Backchannel, underground,
mainline, mainstream, slip

under the radar, caught
off guard, grow the good.

My hood will take
your hood any day.
OK, KK?
Stick it out, wait and see.

Bide our time in these
streets earning some change,
until things change.
Hearts and minds?

On this battlefield
you'll find fragile nerves
of steel mines set to strike.

Oh I stepped on your
toes by airing my woes?

Unloading magazines of
bitter, unrequited love,

tongues blazing, fields
raising, met with only a shrug.

I got my business case in
my briefcase just in case.

I'm the credit to my
race in the boardroom.

In the war room, let's
make a deal trading
likes and followers.
Keeping it real?
Nope, curating the reel.
Stay on your post.

In the back room
all bets are off.

In the green room, allow me
to co-pilot your perception

with my reality brains,
washed in showers of blanks,

spinning truth, dropping
knowledge bombs,

covered in smoke smearing
rainbows and unicorns,
and Officer Friendly.
Remember him?
Nah.

Forget about that
ancestral journey.

They are only mini
me's, no longer "we."

In the bedroom I
infiltrate, I dissipate.
I cohabitate, but don't sleep.

Because in my dreams, I say
the quiet part out loud.
I rest up for the next battle.

It's OK to shed a tear, the
cost of doing business is fear.
More self care?
After my thoughts and prayers.

My grief is jet Black
resistance, the only spark
to make amends.

Red flag, dig deep, yellow flag,
penalty, white flag, retreat,
one really good guy at a time.
What a colossal waste of time.
So how will I win?
I'll win by losing.

It's not either or,
not better or worse.

I'll never win if I
keep being the first.

My final stand ends
with a single word: And.
Thank you.
[APPLAUSE]
